Award.AwardTitle: ABI: A Toolbox for Large-Scale Analysis of Structural Molecular Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
A Toolbox for Large-Scale Analysis of Structural Molecular Data

William Marsh Rice University is awarded a grant to design and implement an extensible and computationally efficient toolbox that integrates sequence information and existing molecular metadata with structural analysis of proteins. One of the most challenging tasks in modern biology is the interpretation of the massive amounts of data becoming available through recent genomics, proteomics and related advances. Proteins are the cell's worker molecules, so there is a tremendous interest to understand how they behave, relate to each other, and how they regulate physiological processes. At the core of the toolbox is a fast and scalable substructure matching method that finds correspondences of a three-dimensional set of atoms (a motif) to a set of protein structures. The goal is to provide biologists with a versatile 'Swiss army knife' for probing the relationship between protein structure and function. The toolbox will be built in a way that it will automatically draw metadata information from relevant online databases in order to be continuously up-to-date. The output will not only report and visualize the results but link to online sources for further evaluation and analysis.

The broader impacts of this project will strengthen biological infrastructure by providing a versatile computational toolbox for the analysis of protein structure and function. The toolbox will be widely disseminated (1) as a web service, (2) as a downloadable package with a command line and Python module interface, and (3) as a plug-in for Chimera, a popular, free molecular modeling program. Besides working with their collaborators, the PIs will reach out to interest groups and related conferences for building a community of users for the proposed tool and encourage the contribution of novel workflows by the scientific community. Students involved in the project will be trained as part of a highly interdisciplinary team, and educational and research activities (through CRA-W, the Computer Research Association's Committee on the Status of Women in Computing Research) for undergraduate students are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The relationships between protein sequence, structure, and function are still poorly understood. In recent years, the increased availability of experimental structures has made it possible to study how subtle structural variations within a protein family affects protein function. We have developed a series of algorithms that solve functional annotation problems of increasing complexity. The first algorithm, called LabelHash, takes as input a structural motif (a spatial arrangement of residues) and returns all statistically significant matches to that motif among all available structures. This can be used to identify other proteins (whose function might unknown) that share a functional site with a protein with known function. This algorithm has been made available as web service at http://labelhash.kavrakilab.org. The second algorithm, called Family-wise Analysis of SubStructural Templates (FASST), builds on the idea of comparing binding sites and applies it to (super-)families of related proteins. We have shown that in many cases the structural variation is not random at all. Instead, we can detect clusterings that closely correlate with, e.g., phylogenetic distance or binding mode. Furthermore, we showed that instead of representing a protein family by a single motif, a so-called motif ensemble can be used in combination with the LabelHash algorithm to more accurately identify related proteins. Finally, the third algorithm automates, to some extent, the motif design process. In many cases, one can identify the functionally most important site in a protein, but which residues are most significant is often hard to determine. Our third algorithm, called Combinational Clustering of Residue Position Subsets (CCORPS), can identify residues that best explain a given "labeling" of structures that belong to a family of related proteins. The labeling can correspond to, e.g., binding affinity for a given drug or a functional annotation like the Enzyme Commission classification. The output of our algorithm can be mapped to residue positions and specific structural variations, thereby providing computational chemists with a powerful tool that can facilitate lead optimization in drug design.The broader impacts of the project have been implemented through software dissemination, web servers, and papers. Several undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students have been trained on the topics of this award. The work affected not only the students who were directly affiliated with this project but also more than 10 graduate and postdoctoral students at the laboratories of the PIs who were exposed to interdisciplinary discussions and work.
